part.narration: Yuki sits at park bench. She fidgets a little. In comes a real Japanese lady and her cute little corgi. Yuki turns to them.
part.line: Oh — you must be Mrs. Sayama —
part.narration: The conversation drones on. The lady asks why Yuki is walking dogs. Yuki tells her that it is because she needs the money. They go on about the economy. Then they go on about how hot it is for August. Then the lady goes on about all of those pesky Pommes. Yuki covers any visible blonde hair with her coolie. The lady strokes the rim of her silk cloche. Yuki takes her mind elsewhere.
part.line: Interactivity brings to us the element missing from all other mediums—
Do you know how to walk my dog?
part.narration: The lady hands her a dog-walking pamphlet. Yuki looks at it.Yuki urges the player to get a look. Oh, the barrier of linguistic communication. No vision text here.Yuki stares at it. To the lady she speaks, softly.
part.line: Static language-dependent representation of a state of affairs —
Not too fond of the written word?
part.narration: The lady walks back and forth across the grass, corgi in leash. Yuki watches it. To the lady she speaks, softly.
part.line: Not a fan of the motion picture?
Take the reins. Walk the dog.
part.narration: The lady gives Yuki the leash. Yuki walks dog. Player walks Yuki. Yuki walks the dog. Back and forth, back and forth. Yuki understands it. To the lady she speaks:
